The cheat for an architect is to Identify the 3-5 discovery candidate‚Äã, that can be delivered in the first sprint successfully. The exploratory 'fail fast' cases should be put for later sprints.

To surmise, as SAP continues to embed AI capabilities into S/4HANA and SAP BTP, the success of enterprise AI initiatives increasingly depends on disciplined discovery rather than experimental implementation. A structured, discovery-first AI assessment enables organizations to align AI use cases with SAP business processes, data realities, and organizational readiness. Joule will accelerate the SAP AI adaptations through its customer base.

For SAP Enterprise Architects, this six-step Discovery-First approach provides a repeatable and scalable framework that complements S/4HANA transformations and positions SAP‚Äôs built-in AI capabilities for sustainable value realization.

entry.title: Generate Client Certificate for Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities via SAP BTP
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

  1. Access to the relevant subaccount in which you want to generate a certificate.
  2.  Admin privileges for the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition system.

Generate Client Certificate 

  1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Connectivity ‚û°Ô∏è Destination Certificates ‚û°Ô∏è click on Create
  2. Under the Generation Method section, choose External service

  3. Under the Generation Details, fill in the following fields:
    1. Name ‚Äì The name you would like to assign to the certificate.
    2. File Extension ‚Äì Leave this field as is, with the value PEM.
    3. Validity ‚Äì Select the desired duration; I chose one year.
    4. Password ‚Äì Although this field is optional, it is required to complete the installation in the system.
    5. Automatic Renewal ‚Äì Set according to your preference; the default value is "On".
  4.  Click on Create.
  5. You will get the following screen:

Download the Client Certificate 

To download the certificate we generated along with its private key, we‚Äôll need to use the Destination Service (Cloud Foundry) API.
The full certificate isn‚Äôt available for download through the SAP BTP admin console.
 
You can find the full API documentation on: https://api.sap.com/api/SAP_CP_CF_Connectivity_Destination/overview 

The API URL is: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.<your_region>.hana.ondemand.com/destination configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates
 
In my example, the region is eu10.
 

For authentication, we need to create an instance of the Destination Service and generate a service key if one does not already exist in our subaccount.

  1. Create a Destension service instance for the authentication details:
    1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Services ‚û°Ô∏è Instances and Subscription ‚û°Ô∏è click on Create.
    2.  Choose the "Destination Service" service, select the "lite" plan, and use a space you have authorization to create an instance in ‚û°Ô∏è click on Create.
    3. After creation, you will see a new instance 
    4. Create a new service key, enter the Service Key Name ‚û°Ô∏è Create.
       

    5. Click on ... ‚û°Ô∏è View
       
The authentication method required for this API is Bearer token authentication.
In my example, I use the Postman client, but you can also work with any other API tool that supports OAuth 2.0 authentication.
 
For the authentication with OAuth 2.0, enter the following fields (when using Pastman):
  1. Grant Type = "Client Credentials" 
  2. Access Token URL = "url" in our service key JSON file with the prefix "/oauth/token"
  3. Client ID = "clientid" in our service key JSON file.
  4. Client Secret = "clientsecret" in our service key JSON file.
  5. Client Authentication = "Send as Basic Auth header".
  6. Click on Get New Access Token ‚û°Ô∏è on the new pop-up window click on Use Token

After we have a token, we can call the API to get our certificate:

The method is GET, and the URL will be https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/{Your Certificate Name}.

In my example, the URL will be: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/J4D_Guide.pem.

The response for the call needs to be like:   

We will get the full certificate, including the private key in base64, and now we need to convert it to text and save it as a PEM certificate.

 
For the conversion, I'm using the terminal on my computer with the command:
echo "base64string" | base64 --decode‚Äã

You will need to replace the "base64string" with your certificate in base64.

The decoded result will be like the example below:

I copied the full result to a text editor and saved it with the PEM extension. 

Load the Client Certificate to the SAP S/4HANA private cloud 

After we have the PEM certificate with the private key, we can proceed and load the certificate to the ABAP system.

  1. Enter the "STRUST" transaction ‚û°Ô∏è on the top toolbar, and click on "Environment" ‚û°Ô∏è and choose "SSL Client Identities of System "

     

  2.  ‚û°Ô∏è Click on the change button. 
  3. Click on "New Entries" ‚û°Ô∏è Enter an Identity and Desctiption ‚û°Ô∏è Click Enter ‚û°Ô∏è Click on Save.
  4. You will need a transport request to save the changes, so create a new one.
  5. The new entry will appear on the left panel
  6. If you are in display mode, click on the change button. once again.
  7. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ‚û°Ô∏è  Import ‚û°Ô∏è PKCS#8/PEM 
  8. In the file browser, choose the file you created in the previous step.
  9. Enter the certification password as entered in the SAP BTP admin portal.
  10. You will see the certificate details:
  11. Click on the check mark to proceed to the next step.
  12. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ‚û°Ô∏è ‚û°Ô∏è Save As...
  13. On the pop-up, choose the SSL Client with the client we created before ‚û°Ô∏è Click on the check mark 
  14. Click on the Save button on the toolbar.

We‚Äôre done üòä
Now all that remains is to import the certificates from the BTP Trust Store and continue configuring Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities.

entry.title: Use Custom Roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Introduction: With the increasing adoption of Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition (PCE), customers are now looking beyond standard business roles and want to control access using custom roles. This becomes especially important when Joule is enabled for selective users, specific business scenarios, or restricted transactional access.

However, configuring custom roles for Joule is not entirely straightforward. It requires a clear understanding of role content, content exposure, and identity provisioning, all of which must work together to ensure Joule can access the required business data and applications.

In this blog, I will walk you through three key topics that will help you successfully use custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA PCE:

1Ô∏è. What a Custom Role Must Contain for Joule to Work Correctly

When using custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, the role definition plays a critical role in determining what Joule can see, understand, and execute. Unlike traditional Fiori usage, Joule depends heavily on Launchpad content, semantic navigation, and backend OData access.

Below are the three key aspects you must consider while designing a custom role.

When creating a custom role, it is essential to ensure that it contains the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs. You can check this SAP Note for the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

To verify this, you should always check the business catalogs that are assigned to your custom role. Business catalogs define which applications, semantic objects, and target mappings are available to the user - and these are what Joule relies on for navigation and execution.

For example, in this scenario, I created a single custom role by reusing a standard SAP business catalog that already contains all Purchase Order related semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

 

By including this required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs in the custom role, Joule can correctly:

  • Resolve Purchase Order related intents
  • Navigate using the appropriate semantic object and action
  • Launch the correct Fiori applications without additional configuration

If you plan to use a Master Role and Derived Role approach, you can create the master role in the same way as described above, ensuring it contains all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app IDs.

Once the master role is created, you can then derive one or more derived roles from it. The derived roles inherit all the authorization content from the master role, while allowing you to maintain organizational-level restrictions if required.

I have also created a derived role from the master role, as shown in the screenshot below. The derived role inherits all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app mappings from the master role, ensuring consistent access behavior for Joule while allowing role assignment at the user level.

2Ô∏è. How to Perform Content Exposure for Custom Roles

üîπV2 Content Exposure (Recommended)

If you are on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition 2023 FPS01 or higher, you must expose your content using Content Exposure Version 2 (V2).

Before exposing content, ensure the following prerequisites are in place.

üîπActivate Required ICF Services

Make sure the following ICF service is active:

  • /sap/bc/http

You can verify and activate this using transaction SICF.

üîπMaintain Design-Time Destination in SAP BTP

In SAP BTP, the design-time destination must include the following service endpoint URL:

<host>/sap/bc/http/ui2/flp_content_exposure/entities

This endpoint is required for SAP Build Work Zone to read exposed content from S/4HANA.

üîπActivate HTTP Service via UCON

Since this is an HTTP-based service, it may need explicit activation.

  • Use transaction UCON_HTTP_SERVICES
  • Activate the service:
  • /UI2/FLP_CONTENT_EXPOSURE

This step is mandatory if the service is restricted by UCON.

üîπRequired Authorization Roles

Ensure the following roles are assigned:

  • Administrator Role
    The administrator must have SAP Fiori Launchpad administration authorizations to expose content to SAP BTP.
  • SAP_FLP_EXP_USER
    Assign this role to the technical user used by SAP Build Work Zone.
    This role allows the user to read and consume exposed content.

üîπWhich Roles Should Be Exposed?

To expose roles, use transaction:

/UI2/CDM3_EXP_SCOPE

Perform the following steps:

  1. Choose Exposure Version = Version 2
  2. Select roles under Areas
    • All selected roles across areas will be exposed
    • You can expose individual roles or group multiple roles under one area

Role Exposure Rules

  • Custom Single Role
    ‚Üí Directly expose the custom role
  • Master & Derived Role Model
    ‚Üí Expose the Master Role only
    (Derived roles cannot be exposed independently)
  • Alternative Approach
    If you do not want to expose the master role:
    • Create a Composite Role
    • Add the required derived roles
    • Expose the composite role

This approach provides flexibility while keeping role design clean.

üîπVerification Steps to Ensure Joule Can Consume the Content

Once the content exposure is completed:

  1. Go to SAP Build Work Zone
  2. Perform a content refresh / update

  3. Verify that:
    • Exposed apps are visible
    • Semantic navigation works
    • Apps can be launched from Work Zone

If the content is visible and accessible in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume and use the exposed content correctly.

3Ô∏è. How to Set Up Identity Provisioning (IPS) to Test Custom Roles

Finally, to validate custom roles with Joule, you must configure the Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) job so that users and roles from SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition are provisioned correctly to SAP Build Work Zone.

In most productive systems, executing a full IPS job can take a significant amount of time, as it processes all users and all roles available in the source S/4HANA PCE system. For testing and validation purposes, it is recommended to limit the scope of provisioning using filters.

üîπWhy Use Filters in IPS?

By applying filters, you can:

  • Provision only specific test users
  • Provision only relevant custom roles
  • Reduce job execution time

üîπRecommended IPS Filters for Testing

In the IPS source system configuration, add the following filters.

Role Filter

Use this filter to provision only the required custom roles.

abap.role.name.filter = (?i)^(ROLE1|ROLE2|ROLE3).*

üîπThis filter:

  • Is case-insensitive ((?i))
  • Provisions only roles matching the specified role names

If you are using a Master and Derived Role model and assign derived roles to users, then you must maintain only the derived roles in this filter. Master roles should not be included unless they are directly assigned to users.

User Filter

Use this filter to provision only the test users.

abap.user.name.filter = ^(USER1|USER2|USER3).*

üîπExecute and Validate the IPS Job

After maintaining the filters:

  1. Run the IPS job
  2. Monitor the job status for errors
  3. Verify in SAP Build Work Zone that:
    • Test users are provisioned
    • Correct roles are assigned

  4. Log in as a test user and validate Joule behavior

If the users and roles are visible and correctly assigned in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume the exposed content and execute actions as expected.

entry.title: SAP Joule Extensibility - With Joule Studio Skill Builder
entry.content:
During TechEd, AI was a central theme across nearly all sessions ‚Äî it was rare to find one where the term ‚ÄúAI‚Äù wasn‚Äôt mentioned. Many of these sessions focused on Joule agents, skills, and the Agent Builder, which is expected to be released by the end of December 2025.

That said, Joule Studio is already available today as part of Build Process Automation. In addition to the upcoming Agent Builder, it is currently possible to extend Joule‚Äôs capabilities using Custom Joule Skills through the Joule Skill Builder.

To put it simply, we are still running S/4HANA 2022 FPS02, and features such as Sales Order Fulfillment and Monitoring (SAP Note 3459573) via Joule are only available in later releases. As a result, asking Joule transactional questions related to Sales Orders does not yield any response.

Here‚Äôs where the Joule Skill Builder in Joule Studio comes into play.

We could create a custom skill and leverage existing BAPIs in the S/4HANA system. (First, a destination must be configured in the BPA BTP subaccount to establish the connection with the S/4 system.)

Once the S/4 system is accessible from BPA via this destination, the next step is to define actions‚Äîspecifying which fields, tasks, and data should be retrieved from S/4 using the relevant BAPIs (in this case, those related to Sales Orders).

The only mandatory input field required is the Sales Document Number; all other fields have been excluded from the selection.

The following are the only output fields (or outputs) of interest for this Joule Skill.

Once the Action is defined, we‚Äôre ready to build our first basic Joule Skill. I‚Äôll include a few numbered screenshots to illustrate the process and explain the overall flow.

 

Once the skill is deployed in your BPA environment, you can grant and share access to other users using the Share option. To test the skill, simply launch the standalone Joule using the Launch button.

The skill can also be deployed and made available to the central/shared Joule instance that is enabled across the SAP landscape, encompassing both private and public cloud systems and services (via Joule Formation).

Now we can retry the same Sales Order queries to check if Joule can provide meaningful responses. This time, I invoked Joule directly from our S/4HANA system, rather than launching it as a standalone instance from BPA.

Although this functionality is not natively supported in the S/4HANA version we are currently running, we successfully extended Joule‚Äôs capabilities by creating custom skills to address a simple, practical use case.

Disclaimer: An additional skill was also developed to demonstrate the Card with Buttons feature; however, it is not covered here üôÇ

Helpful Links

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Set Up Joule Studio

Mission in Discovery Center

entry.title: SAP Joule Document Grounding (Business AI)
entry.content:
t‚Äôs finally time to explore Document Grounding and train Joule to answer questions using your company‚Äôs specific policy and knowledge documents. But before diving into Joule, it‚Äôs important to first understand Retrieval Augmented Generation.

 

  • Retrieval: When you ask a question, the system first searches a database, documents, or knowledge source (like a company‚Äôs files, research papers) for the relevant information.
  • Augmentation: Those retrieved documents are passed into the language model as extra context.
  • Generation: The model then uses both its own knowledge and the retrieved information to produce an answer that is more accurate and grounded in facts.

 

This helps reduce hallucinations (when an AI makes things up) and allows the model to answer questions about data it wasn‚Äôt originally trained on.

In line with the general SAP documentation approach, we used SharePoint as the content ingestion platform. This means that once you create and execute a data pipeline, documents from your selected SharePoint sites and folders are successfully ingested into the pipeline. After ingestion, Joule can leverage this information to augment its responses.

The setup is technically intensive. For those interested in testing this out‚Äîand to avoid overloading this post with technical jargon‚Äîthe SAP TechEd session on Setting up Joule to answer questions in your own policy documents is the best starting point.

We used Bruno as the tool to setup a data pipeline between SharePoint and BTP subaccount running Joule.

 

Below are a couple of examples where we set up a data pipeline to make Joule aware of Kardex (Kardex is an Automatic Storage Retrieval System). We also ingested specific HR policy documents.

As a result, when queried, Joule is contextually aware of this information and provides grounded responses specific to this knowledge base.

 

Be prepared for some issues and challenges during the deployment along the way and reference this great post " Joule ‚Äì Getting Started with Document Grounding"to solve some of them

Pre-Requisites for using Joule Document Grounding:

  • You‚Äôve purchased the AI Unit SKU (8019164) and AI units.
  • You‚Äôve added the entitlements for document grounding to the subaccount where you‚Äôve subscribed to Joule.
  • You‚Äôve enabled Identity Authentication with Cloud Identity Services

entry.title: Hands-On Guide: SAP Build + Joule Skill for Purchase Order Listing, Approval, or Modification
entry.content:
Introduction

In this tutorial, we will build an AI powered Purchase Order listing, modification or approval app using SAP Build and Joule. This step by step guide covers everything from OData integration to creating a working Joule Skill.

 

Table of Contents

  • 1. Create an Environment
  • 2. Exposing the Destination
  • 3. Create a database table to store purchase orders
  • 4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata
  • 5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW
  • 6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code
  • 7. Crete an Action in SAP Build
  • 8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order
  • 9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order
  • 10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

 

In today‚Äôs SAP ecosystem, intelligent automation is an expectation, not a future goal. SAP Build allows developers to quickly create business applications without extensive coding and SAP Joule brings AI-driven intelligence to these experiences.

In this hands-on guide, I‚Äôll walk you through the process of building a Joule skill that connects to an OData service, allowing users to list, approve, and update purchase orders directly through SAP Build. ( This guide uses ZTABLE to store purchase order data because the standard SAP tables in the test system I work on don't have enough or the right kind of data. However, you can use the standard tables instead of ZTABLE. )

This project shows how AI capabilities can seamlessly integrate into SAP‚Äôs low-code environment, enabling automation and human decision-making in one interface. Whether you want to enhance your workflow with intelligent actions or explore real-world Joule integration scenarios, this guide will provide a practical starting point.

 

1. Create an Environment

 

We need to create an environment for testing joule skill.

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments and press the Create button.

 

 

Name your environment and add Description.

 

2. Exposing the Destination

 

Url of the destination on BTP is the url of our SAP system and the destination must have these properties: 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled -> true

sap.processautomation.enabled -> true

sap.build.usage -> odata_gen

 

Also the destination‚Äôs user will be used for set an external break-point for debugging the ABAP code.

 

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Destinations and press the Add button.

 

Select the Destination and choose next.

 

Choose the environment in which you want to use the target. For this tutorial you can choose the Test Environment that you create.

 

3. Create a database table to store purchase orders

@EndUserText.label : 'Purchase Order Change With Sap Build'
@AbapCatalog.enhancementCategory : #NOT_CLASSIFIED
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zbg_build_test {
  key mandt                      : mandt not null;
  key purchaseorder              : ebeln not null;
  key purchaseorderitem          : ebelp not null;
  key reservationitem            : ebelp not null;
  material                       : matnr;
  materialcompisvariablesized    : boolean;
  materialcomponentisphantomitem : boolean;
  reservation                    : char10;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  requiredquantity               : menge_d;
  requirementdate                : dats;
  reservationisfinallyissued     : boolean;
  baseunit                       : meins;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  quantityinentryunit            : menge_d;
  entryunit                      : meins;
  plant                          : werks_d;
  latestrequirementdate          : dats;
  billofmaterialitemnumber       : ebelp;
  bomitemcategory                : char1;
  isbulkmaterialcomponent        : boolean;
  debitcreditcode                : shkzg;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  withdrawnquantity              : menge_d;
  approver                       : uname;
  appoved                        : flag;

}

 

Fill the table:

 

 

4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata

 

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSLV_BUILD_TST_V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchasing Document Informations CDS'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.deleteEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.createEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.updateEnabled: true
define view ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST as select from zbg_build_test as z 
    
{   @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order'
    key purchaseorder,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order Item'
    key purchaseorderitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Item'
    key reservationitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material'
    material,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Size'
    materialcompisvariablesized,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Item'
    materialcomponentisphantomitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation'
    reservation,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity'
    requiredquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Date'
    requirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Issue'
    reservationisfinallyissued,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Unit'
    baseunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Entry Unit'
    entryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity In Entry Unit'
    quantityinentryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Plant'
    plant,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Latest Requirement Date'
    latestrequirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Bill Of Material Number'
    billofmaterialitemnumber,
    @EndUserText.label: 'BOM Item Category'
    bomitemcategory,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Is Bulk Material'
    isbulkmaterialcomponent,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Debit Credit Code'
    debitcreditcode,
    @EndUserText.label: 'With Drawn Quantity'
    withdrawnquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approver'
    approver,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approved'
    appoved 
    
}

 

5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW

(Because of the version of the system I work on, this guide uses SEGW instead of RAP to create an OData service. However, you can easily create your own OData service with RAP.)

Press ‚ÄòCreate Project‚Äô button, fill the fields and assign the package, request (For this tutorial it will be local object).

 

Complete the creation.

 

Extend the project, right click to ‚ÄòData Model‚Äô, select the Reference->Source

 

 

Fill the CDS name that you created. Choose ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

Choose ‚ÄòFinish‚Äô.

 

 

Activate and generate the Service:

 

 

Go to the class ZCL_ZSLV_BUILD_DPC_EXT. At the bottom of the method list redefine the update method ZSLV_V_BUILD_TES_UPDATE_ENTITY.

 

 

In the method, update the approved field with the below code and activate it.

 

METHOD zslv_v_build_tes_update_entity.
 
  DATA: lv_ebeln TYPE ebeln,
        lv_ebelp TYPE ebelp,
        lv_item  TYPE ebelp,
        ls_entity TYPE zcl_zslv_build_mpc=>ts_zslv_v_build_testtype,
        lr_entity TYPE REF TO data,
        ls_table TYPE zbg_build_test.
 
  LOOP AT it_key_tab INTO DATA(ls_key).
    CASE ls_key-name.
      WHEN 'purchaseorder'.
        lv_ebeln = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'purchaseorderitem'.
        lv_ebelp = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'reservationitem'.
        lv_item = ls_key-value.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.
 
  io_data_provider->read_entry_data( IMPORTING es_data = ls_entity ).
  MOVE-CORRESPONDING ls_entity TO ls_table.
  er_entity = ls_entity.
  UPDATE zbg_build_test FROM ls_table.
  COMMIT WORK.
 
ENDMETHOD.

 

6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code

 

Choose ‚ÄòAdd Service‚Äô

 

 

Select the ‚ÄòSystem Alias‚Äô, fill the ‚ÄòTechnical Service Name‚Äô and press ‚ÄòGet Services‚Äô. Select the service that you create and press ‚ÄòAdd Selected Services‚Äô.

 

 

Assign the package and continue.

 

 

We have added the service, which should appear as follows. In the ICF Nodes section, there is a button labeled "SAP Gateway Client" that provides a testing environment for the service. Press that button.

 

 

Select the HTTP method as ‚ÄòGET‚Äô. Press ‚ÄòEntitySets‚Äô to choose entity set. Choose the one that you created.

 

 

Press ‚ÄòExecute‚Äô button for testing and response should appear as follows.

 

 

7. Crete an Action in SAP Build

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Connectors->Actions and press the ‚ÄòCreate‚Äô button. Choose ‚ÄòOData Destinations‚Äô and select the Destination that we created.

 

 

Fill the Resource Path as follows and click ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

The available methods are listed in this window. Select ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

Fill the name and description for your action and create.

 

 

The action Purchase_Order_Action is created. Click the action and open it.

 

 

Select the methods in the OData Service.

 

 

The GET method's input has no required fields, only optional GET parameters.

 

 

Output parameters are the fields in the CDS that we created. 

 

 

Methods can be tested in the action interface. For the GET method we don‚Äôt need to fill any input parameters. Click ‚ÄòTest‚Äô button.

 

 

The data appears on the ‚ÄòTest Preview‚Äô section.

 

 

The PATCH method requires purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem, all of which are key fields in our ZTABLE and CDS.

 

 

There are no standard output in PATCH method.

 

 

In the Test section, all required fields and fields that need to be changed must be filled out. In this scenario these fields are purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem, reservationitem and approved fields.

 

Also the link on the Test section can be used in the SAP Gateway Client to test the PATCH method.

 

 

 

PATCH method return ‚Äú204: NO CONTENT‚Äù and empty Response. This means the update is successful and we will use this emptiness in our joule skill.

 

 

After checking and testing, save the methods using the ‚ÄòSave‚Äô button and select ‚ÄòRelease‚Äô. After the release process, the action should appear as shown below. Then, press 'Publish'.

 

 

You can debug when testing methods via the SAP Gateway Client or the SAP Build Action. Set an external breakpoint for the user in your destination that we created at the beginning.

 

 

For the PATCH method, our key fields in the internal table IT_KEY_TAB. 

 

 

8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Create->Joule Skill and fill the name and description. Open the created skill.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄôTrigger‚Äô step. On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab fill the name and description. Allow Joule to generate a response and skill to be started directly by user.

 

 

We don't need input, but outputs can vary according to our needs. In this tutorial, the parameters shown below have been added as outputs.

Choose ‚ÄòConfigure‚Äô and add parameters you want to show to the user. For this example, all parameters are string except the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô which is boolean.

 

 

 

Press ‚Äò+‚Äô and choose ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô, ‚ÄòBrowse All Actions‚Äô.

 

 

Search for ‚ÄòZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô or your Service Name. Add the ‚ÄòGet entities from ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄòDestination Variable‚Äô as Destination we created. 

 

 

We can skip the input tab because there are no input for GET method.

 

 

We can see the output parameters in this tab.

 

 

On the "End" step, we need to assign the input and output parameters for the skills. Since we don't have any inputs, let's assign the outputs added in the "Trigger" step as our action's outputs.

 

 

Save the Joule Skill.

 

 

And Release.

 

 

Now Deploy.

 

 

Choose the Environment we created and click ‚ÄòUpgrade‚Äô.

 

 

Match the destinations, and the skill will be ready to use by Joule after deployment.

 

 

9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order

 

On the ‚ÄòTrigger‚Äô step, fill the name and description. Deactivate the ‚ÄòAllow Joule to generate a response‚Äô feature because in this skill we will create our own messages. The other feature should be active.

 

 

Configure the input parameters. Add purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem key fields as string. For approve skill we don‚Äôt need any output field.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô.

 

 

Browse All Actions.

 

 

Search update or the service name. Add the Update entity in ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab, assign the Destination.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòInputs‚Äô tab, assign the purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem to the parameters created on the "Trigger" step.

 

 

We only need to fill the fields ‚Äòapproved‚Äô from the fields to be updated. We need to configure the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field because action inputs can only be string. 

 

Choose ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field and ‚ÄòApply a formula‚Äô.

 

Type ‚Äòtrue‚Äô and click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCheck Condition‚Äô.

 

 

Choose the ‚ÄòCondition Editor‚Äô.

 

 

Add the following conditions and Click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô. If PATCH method is executed successfully, the result will be empty. 

 

 

If the condition is met, the left branch of the condition executes. In the opposite case, the ‚ÄòDefault‚Äô branch of the condition executes.

 

Choose the ‚Äò+‚Äô on the left branch and ‚ÄòSend Response‚Äô.

 

 

Open Message Editor.

 

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

You can add parameters to the title and message with the ‚Äò<>‚Äô button.

 

 

Do the same steps for the right branch of the condition. ‚Äò+‚Äô -> ‚ÄôSend Response‚Äô -> ‚ÄòOpen Message Editor‚Äô

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

Save, Release and Deploy just like the previous GET_PURCHASE_ORDER skill.

 

10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments->Joule

 

 

Launch the joule, ask for Purchase Orders and get the details.

 

 

Ask joule to approve the purchase orders and get the illustrated success message card we create.

entry.title: New Expert-Guided Implementation: Joule Prerequisites¬†and¬†Activation
entry.content:
Establish the Foundation for Your AI Journey 

SAP Joule is transforming how organizations interact with SAP applications by bringing intelligence directly into everyday workflows. For customers to activate Joule and unlock its AI-powered capabilities, they must first prepare their SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS), SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and integration foundations to fully realize the value of Joule from day one. 

To support customers with this essential preparation, we are pleased to introduce a new Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI):  

Joule Prerequisites & Activation - a hands-on, expert-led program designed to help you configure all required technical components for a smooth Joule activation. 

This new offering helps customers understand Joule‚Äôs architecture, explore deployment options, configure platform prerequisites, and establish the identity and access foundation required for a secure activation. By the end of the EGI, participants will be positioned to complete all the prerequisites required to activate Joule, ensuring a seamless start to their AI adoption journey. 

 

Workshop Schedule  

To accommodate global participants, this session will be offered on the following dates and time zones as follows: 

2026 Dates 

Time 

Time Zone‚ÄØ 

Jan 19-20 

10:00AM - 12:00PM 

EMEA | CET

10:00AM - 12:00PM

10:00AM-12:00PM

10:00AM - 12:00PM

10:00AM - 12:00PM

10:00AM-12:00PM 

NA/LA | EST

 

Why This EGI Matters 

Before Joule can be activated, customers must ensure the right technical prerequisites are in place‚Äîacross SAP BTP, Cloud Identity Services, Build Work Zone, and Line-of-Business systems. This EGI provides: 

  • A clear, step-by-step path to completing these prerequisites 
  • Expert-led guidance for setting up SAP Cloud Identity Services including Identity Authentication Service (IAS)/Identity Provisioning Service (IPS), and entitlements 
  • Live configuration guidance in your SAP BTP environment and SAP Build Workzone (BWZ) 
  • Hands-on support through real examples and troubleshooting 

With AI rapidly becoming central to SAP‚Äôs product strategy, organizations need the right technical foundation to adopt Joule with confidence, security, and scalability. 

 

What You‚Äôll Learn: Program Overview 

This 2-day EGI blends instruction, demonstrations, and guided hands-on exercises. 

Day 1 ‚Äì Foundation & Architecture 

  • Understand Joule‚Äôs system architecture and deployment scenarios 
  • Learn how SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS/IPS), SAP BTP, SAP Build Work Zone, and LOB solutions work together 
  • Navigate BTP global accounts, subaccounts, entitlements, and subscriptions 
  • Validate system readiness and begin configuring your Joule environment 
  • Experience a live demonstration of Joule integrated with SAP SuccessFactors 

 

Day 2 ‚Äì Identity, Provisioning & Work Zone Integration 

  • Deep-dive into SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS) and Identity Provisioning (IPS) for Joule 
  • Integrate CIS with your corporate Identity Provider 
  • Configure SAP Build Workzone (BWZ) as the unified interface for Joule 
  • Establish trust relationships between systems 
  • Expose LOB content to BWZ and validate provisioning flows 

 

What You Will Achieve 

This new EGI equips your organization with everything needed to prepare for Joule activation, ensuring compliance, security, and a streamlined technical foundation from day one. 

If your organization is planning to adopt SAP Joule or preparing for AI-driven innovation within SAP applications, this EGI is the ideal starting point to fast-track your readiness and reduce implementation risk. 

By the end of the EGI, you will have: 

  • A configured SAP BTP environment with a designated Joule subaccount 
  • Completed IAS/IPS setup for secure authentication and provisioning 
  • Integrated BWZ as the experience layer for Joule 
  • Verified all activation prerequisites using a comprehensive readiness checklist 
  • Gained expert-backed confidence to run the Joule Booster and proceed with activation 

  
How to Register 
 Update the link below once the EGI is published on the Learning Hub 

 

Register here to secure your spot*‚ÄØtoday to learn from SAP experts and gain the skills to adopt and activate Joule across your enterprise. 

‚ÄØ*‚ÄØYou may need to register your S-user for access to SAP Learning Hub to access the EGI registration page.‚ÄØ It is a one-time registration, click‚ÄØhere.

entry.title: Train Joule AI for SAP ECC: Step-by-Step Guide: How to Create a Joule Skill for SAP ECC
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

SAP Joule is SAP‚Äôs AI copilot that helps users perform business tasks using natural language. A Joule skill is a defined capability that allows Joule to answer questions or trigger actions in SAP systems.

SAP Joule is not natively built for direct integration with SAP ECC (Enterprise Core Component). It is primarily designed as a cloud native AI copilot for SAP's cloud solutions, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP SuccessFactors.

However, customers on ECC can still leverage some of Joule's capabilities through hybrid approaches using the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  This blog explains how to design and create a Joule skill that works with SAP ECC, using SAP‚Äôs recommended tools and architecture.

Step 1: Understand What a Joule Skill Is

A Joule skill consists of:

  • A user intent (what the user asks Joule)
  • Business logic (what happens behind the scenes)
  • System integration (ECC in this case)
  • A structured response back to the user

Example:

‚ÄúJoule, show me the open sales orders for top problematic customer ABC.‚Äù

Step 2: Identify the Use Case in SAP ECC

Start with a simple, high value use case.

Good examples

  • Check sales order status of top 5 customers
  • Customer 360 degree snapshots
  • Display open invoices
  • Get material stock levels
  • Which orders are delayed today?
  • Which materials are at risk this week?
  • What is product costing for X product in last 5 years? Where am I spending more money?

Define clearly:

  • What data is needed from ECC
  • Which transaction or table provides it
  • Whether it‚Äôs read only or triggers an action

Why it‚Äôs great:

  • Sales + Finance or Procurement+Finance in one answer
  • Simple answers to today's painful questions
  • Very executive-friendly and great for planners without systems

Step 3: Prepare SAP ECC for Integration

Joule does not connect directly to ECC. You need an API layer.

Common integration options:

  • OData services (via SAP Gateway)
  • RFC / BAPI exposed through SAP Integration Suite
  • IDocs (less common for Joule)

Actions:

  1. Identify the ECC function module or BAPI
  2. Expose it as an OData service or API
  3. Test the API independently

Example:

  • BAPI_SALESORDER_GETSTATUS
  • BAPI_CUSTOMER_GETDETAIL

Step 4: Set Up SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

Joule skills are built and orchestrated on SAP BTP. You will need:

  • SAP BTP account
  • SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP Build Process Automation or Build Apps
  • SAP AI Core / AI Launchpad (if using advanced AI logic)

Ensure:

  • ECC is connected securely to BTP
  • Authentication (OAuth / Principal Propagation) is configured

Step 5: Create the Business Logic (Skill Backend)

Now you define what the skill actually does.

Options:

  • SAP Build Process Automation (recommended)
  • SAP Build Apps
  • CAP (Cloud Application Programming) model

Steps:

  1. Create a process or service
  2. Consume the ECC API
  3. Map input parameters (e.g., customer number)
  4. Format the output clearly for Joule

Example output:

  • Sales order number
  • Status
  • Delivery date

Step 6: Define the Joule Skill (Intent)

This is where Joule learns how users talk.

You define:

  • Skill name
  • User intent
  • Sample phrases

Examples:

  • ‚ÄúShow open sales orders for customer 10001‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhat is the status of sales order 4500001234?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúCheck customer ABC orders‚Äù

These help Joule understand variations in natural language.

Step 7: Connect Joule to the Backend Logic

Now connect:

  • The user intent
  • To the backend service or process

Actions:

  • Map extracted parameters (order number, customer ID)
  • Trigger the ECC API call
  • Capture the response
  • Return structured data to Joule

Step 8: Design the Response Experience

Joule responses should be:

  • Short
  • Clear
  • Actionable

Examples:

  • Text summary
  • Bullet points
  • Table Style

Bad response:

‚ÄúHere is the data you requested.‚Äù

Good response:

‚ÄúCustomer ABC has 3 open sales orders. The next delivery is scheduled for 12 Oct.‚Äù

Step 9: Test the Joule Skill

Testing is critical.

Test scenarios:

  • Valid and Invalid input
  • Missing parameters
  • Incorrect values
  • No data found
  • Performance delays

Test in:

  • SAP Joule preview
  • BTP logs
  • ECC backend logs

Step 10: Secure and Authorize the Skill

Ensure:

  • Only authorized users can access ECC data
  • Role based access is enforced
  • Sensitive fields are masked if needed

Use:

  • SAP Identity Authentication (IAS)
  • Role collections in BTP
  • ECC authorization objects

Step 11: Deploy and Enable for Users

Once tested:

  1. Deploy the backend service
  2. Activate the Joule skill
  3. Assign it to user roles
  4. Enable it in the SAP application where Joule is use

Step 12: Monitor and Improve

After go live:

  • Monitor usage
  • Review failed queries
  • Expand to new ECC use cases

Over time, Joule becomes smarter and more valuable.

What works?

Creating a Joule skill for SAP ECC involves:

  • Clear business use cases
  • API based ECC integration
  • SAP BTP orchestration
  • Well designed natural language interaction

While ECC is a legacy system, Joule allows it to be used in a modern, conversational way.

#SAP #Deloitte #AIinSAP #Joule #SAPECC #SAPJoule #SAPBTP #EnterpriseAI #AI #Interim

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 1

Introduction

SAP Joule enables users to interact with enterprise data using natural language, turning complex analytics into actionable insights. When integrated with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) through SAP Build Work Zone, Joule becomes a powerful interface for consuming analytical content securely and seamlessly.

In this blog we will start the integration step-by-step including subaccount setup, identity provisioning, destination configuration, SAP Build Work Zone setup, and SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Prerequisites

Before starting the integration, ensure the following foundational setup is completed. These steps establish the required SAP BTP subaccounts, spaces, and identity services used throughout the configuration.

1. Create the Main BTP Subaccount for Joule and Work Zone

This subaccount hosts SAP Build Work Zone, Joule, and runtime configurations.

  1. Create a new SAP BTP Subaccount
    Example name:    JouleBATTesting

  2. Enable the Cloud Foundry environment for the subaccount.
  3. Within the subaccount, create a Cloud Foundry Space:
    Example: JouleSpace
  4. Leave all checkboxes at their default values during space creation.

2. Create a Dedicated Subaccount for Identity Provisioning (IdP)

A separate subaccount is recommended for managing identity provisioning and synchronization across systems.

  1. Create a new SAP BTP Subaccount
    Example name: JouleIDP
  2. Enable the Cloud Foundry environment.
  3. Create a Cloud Foundry Space:
    Example: JouleIDPSpace

3. Enable Cloud Identity Services in the IdP Subaccount

  1. In the JouleIDP subaccount, navigate to:
    Entitlements ‚Üí Configure Entitlements

  2. Add the following service:
    Service: Cloud Identity Services
    Plan: additional-tenant (Application)
  3. Save the entitlement configuration.

4. Create or Subscribe to Cloud Identity Services

You can create the service either from the Service Marketplace or Instances and Subscriptions.

Option A: Using Service Marketplace

  1. Go to Service Marketplace.

  2. Search for Cloud Identity Services.
  3. Select Service Plans and choose additional-tenant.
  4. Assign the service to the space JouleIDPSpace (if not already created).
  5. Create a new instance or subscription.
Option B: Using Instances and Subscriptions

  1. Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions ‚Üí Create.

  2. Select:
    Service: Cloud Identity Services
    Plan: additional-tenant
  3. Click Next.
  4. Choose:
    Service Type: TEST (or as per your landscape requirement)
  5. Complete the creation.

Configure Trust and Enable SAP Build Work Zone

All steps below are performed in the JouleBATTesting subaccount.

5. Establish Trust with the Identity Provider

To allow users provisioned through IPS to authenticate correctly, trust must be established.

Procedure

  1. Go to Security ‚Üí Trust Configuration

  2. Choose Establish Trust
  3. Select the custom IdP created earlier
  4. Click Next ‚Üí Finish

‚úî Trust is now established between the Joule subaccount and the IdP.

6. Generate Destination Trust

  1. Navigate to Connectivity ‚Üí Destination Trust

  2. Click Generate Trust

This enables secure communication between destinations and subscribed services.

7. Assign SAP Build Work Zone Entitlements

Procedure

  1. Go to Entitlements ‚Üí Configure Entitlements

  2. Search for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition
  3. Select the following service plans:
    standard
    standard (Application)
  4. Click Add Service Plans and Save

8. Subscribe to SAP Build Work Zone

  1. Navigate to Services ‚Üí Instances and Subscriptions

  2. Under Subscriptions, choose Create
  3. Select:
    Service: SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition
    Plan: standard
  4. Click Create

9. Create SAP Build Work Zone Instance

  1. In Instances, click Create

  2. Provide the following values:
    Runtime Environment: Cloud Foundry
    Space: JouleSpace
    Instance Name: SWZJoule (user-defined)
  3. Click Next ‚Üí Finish

10. Create and Download the Service Key

  1. Open the instance SWZJoule

  2. From the three-dot menu (‚ãÆ), choose Create Service Key
  3. Enter:
    Service Key Name: SWZInstanceKey
  4. Create the key and download the JSON file

This file will be used later for destination and IPS configuration.

11. Import Navigation Service Destination

This destination enables navigation between SAP Build Work Zone and Joule.

Procedure

  1. Navigate to Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations (Legacy)

  2. Choose Import Destination
  3. Import the provided template:
    NavigationService-TEMPL
  4. Update the destination properties using values from the service key:

    Property Value
    Name NavigationService
    URL Portal URL from service key JSON
    Client ID clientid
    Client Secret clientsecret
    Token Service URL <url>/token
  5. Save the destination

Enable Joule and Run the Joule Booster

 

For further configuration refer
SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 2

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 2

Introduction

In Part 1, we completed the foundational setup for SAP Joule by:

  • Creating SAP BTP subaccounts and spaces
  • Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Enabling SAP Build Work Zone
  • Running the Joule Booster to establish system formations

In Part 2, we complete the integration by connecting SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to SAP Build Work Zone and Joule. This includes:

  • OAuth client creation in SAC
  • Design-time and runtime destination configuration
  • Content provider creation
  • Role consumption
  • User and role provisioning using Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)
  • Final Joule validation

Create OAuth Clients in SAP Analytics Cloud

To allow SAP Build Work Zone and Joule to securely access SAP Analytics Cloud content, OAuth clients must be configured in SAC.

SAP documentation reference:
Consume Role Definition Content from SAP Analytics Cloud

1. Create OAuth Client for Design-Time Access

The design-time OAuth client is used to:

  • Read SAC role definitions
  • Import analytical metadata into SAP Build Work Zone

Procedure

  1. Log in to SAP Analytics Cloud
  2. Navigate to:
    System ‚Üí Administration ‚Üí App Integration
  3. Under Configured Clients, choose Add an OAuth Client
  4. Maintain the following values:
    Name: sac-buildworkzone-dt (example)
    Purpose: API Access
    Access: User Provisioning
    Authorization Grant: Client Credentials
  5. Configure Token Lifetime:
    Positive integer value
    Units: minutes, hours, or days
    If not specified, the token lifetime is infinite
  6. Click Add

Save Credentials

  • Copy and store the Client ID
  • Click Copy Secret and save the Client Secret
  • Note the Token Service URL

Important
The client secret is displayed only once and cannot be retrieved later.

OAuth Clients Summary

After completing this step, you should have two OAuth clients in SAP Analytics Cloud:

1. Runtime OAuth Client (Auto-created by Joule Booster)

  • Created automatically during Joule booster execution
  • Used at runtime by Joule
  • Uses SAML Bearer Assertion
  • Client secret cannot be copied

2. Design-Time OAuth Client (Manually Created)

  • Used for:
    Importing SAC roles
    Reading analytical metadata
  • Client ID and secret are used in SAP BTP destinations

Create Design-Time Destination in SAP BTP

This destination enables SAP Build Work Zone to read role definitions from SAP Analytics Cloud.

Procedure

  1. Sign in to the JouleBATTesting subaccount
  2. Navigate to:
    Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations
  3. Click Create Destination

Destination Configuration

PropertyValue
NameSAC_SWZ_DT
TypeHTTP
URLhttps://<SAC-domain>/api/v1/cdm
Proxy TypeInternet
AuthenticationOAuth2ClientCredentials
Client IDSAC design-time OAuth Client ID
Client SecretSAC design-time OAuth Client Secret
Token Service URL TypeDedicated
Token Service URL Token URL from SAC OAuth configuration

Additional Properties

PropertyValue
HTML5.SetXForwardedHeadersfalse
URL.headers.x-sap-sac-custom-auth true

4. Click Save

Create Runtime Destination by Cloning

Instead of manually creating a runtime destination, reuse the destination created automatically by the Joule booster.

Procedure

  1. Go to:
    Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations
  2. Locate destination:
    DYN_SAC_SSO
  3. Click Clone
  4. Provide a new name:
    SAC_SWZ_RT

Additional Properties

PropertyValue
sap-card-nominations-path/api/v1/interest-cards
sap-start true
 
5. Save the destination



Assign Required Roles to Users

Before proceeding, ensure the user has required roles.

Procedure

  1. Go to:
    Subaccount ‚Üí Security ‚Üí Users
  2. Assign the following roles to the IdP user:
    Launchpad_Admin
    Launchpad_External_User

Create Content Provider in SAP Build Work Zone

This step imports SAC content and role definitions into SAP Build Work Zone.

Procedure

  1. Go to Service Marketplace
  2. Open SAP Build Work Zone
  3. Choose Go to Application
  4. Navigate to Channel Manager
  5. Click + New Content Provider

Content Provider Configuration

PropertyValue
Titlesac.analytics
DescriptionSAP Analytics Cloud content
IDsac.analytics
Design-Time DestinationSAC_SWZ_DT
Runtime DestinationSAC_SWZ_RT
Runtime Destination for Dynamic DataDefault
Automatically add contentEnabled
Use IPS for authorizationsEnabled

6. Click Save

Results

  • SAC role definitions are imported into SAP Build Work Zone
  • System Owner role is intentionally not imported
  • Role changes in SAC require manual refresh from Channel Manager

Provision Users Using Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)

To allow users to access analytical insights via Joule, users, roles, and permissions must be synced from SAC to SAP Build Work Zone.

1. Configure SAP Analytics Cloud as Source System

Reference: SAP Analytics Cloud IPS documentation

Procedure

  1. Open SAP Cloud Identity Services Admin Console
  2. Navigate to:
    Identity Provisioning ‚Üí Source Systems
  3. Add SAP Analytics Cloud as a source system

Mandatory Properties

PropertyValue
TypeHTTP
URLSAC base URL (no path)
ProxyTypeInternet
AuthenticationBasicAuthentication
UserSAC OAuth Client ID
PasswordSAC OAuth Client Secret
OAuth2TokenServiceURLSAC token service URL
sac.api.version2 (recommended)




2. Configure Transformations

  • Navigate to Transformations
  • Paste the JSON from:
    Default transformation for SAP Analytics Cloud SCIM API v2

3. Configure SAP Build Work Zone as Target System

Reference: SAP Build Work Zone IPS documentation

  • Use the service key JSON from SWZInstanceKey
  • Configure:
    API URL
    OAuth client ID
    OAuth client secret
  • Use default transformation from SAP documentation





Run Provisioning Jobs

Simulate Provisioning

  1. Go to SAC Source System ‚Üí Jobs
  2. Click Run Now on Simulate Job
  3. Verify logs:
    Identity Provisioning ‚Üí Provisioning Logs

‚úî No errors should appear

Execute Provisioning

  1. Run Read Job
  2. Check provisioning logs again

Validate User Provisioning

  1. Log in to SAP Build Work Zone as Launchpad_Admin
  2. Go to:
    Settings ‚Üí Identity Provisioning
  3. Enter SAC user email
  4. Validate role IDs are correctly assigned

Create Joule User Role Collection

Procedure

  1. Create User (ex - testuser@test.com)
  2. Go to JouleBATTesting ‚Üí Security ‚Üí Role Collections
  3. Create role collection:
    Joule_User
  4. Add:
    Joule roles
    Launchpad_Admin (if site admin access is required)
  5. Assign role collection to IdP users
  6. Log out and log back in









Index Data Using Just Ask and Validate Joule

Reference: SAP Joule documentation

Important Validation Rules

  • SAC models must:
    Belong to the same user
    Be indexed under Just Ask using the same identity
  • Example user:
    testuser@test.com

If models are indexed under a different user, Joule will not return results.





SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 1

Reference Link
https://help.sap.com/doc/de3af3c0f81642dbaa4d36172ed57a72/CLOUD/en-US/79bfc83ab386450c8cd9c7937ce26a3a.pdf

Thanks
Ashraf
